en: But here were books, and here were men who had penetrated deeper and knew more. I took their word for all that they averred, and I became their disciple. It may appear strange that such should arise in the eighteenth century; but while I followed the routine of education in the schools of Geneva, I was, to a great degree, self-taught with regard to my favourite studies. My father was not scientific, and I was left to struggle with a child’s blindness, added to a student’s thirst for knowledge. Under the guidance of my new preceptors I entered with the greatest diligence into the search of the philosopher’s stone and the elixir of life; but the latter soon obtained my undivided attention. Wealth was an inferior object, but what glory would attend the discovery if I could banish disease from the human frame and render man invulnerable to any but a violent death!

vi: Nhưng đây thực sự là sách, và đây là những người đã đào sâu hơn và hiểu nhiều hơn. Họ khẳng định thế nào, tôi nhất nhất tin từng lời thế ấy, tôi trở thành môn đồ của họ. Cũng lạ lùng là ở thế kỷ mười tám còn có sự tình như vậy; nhưng trong khi theo đúng lối học quy định tại các trường ở Geneva, tôi chủ yếu vẫn là tự học, chỉ giới hạn trong những ngành mình thích. Cha tôi không biết nhiều về khoa học, tôi phải tự vật lộn với sự ngu dốt của một đứa bé, lại còn thêm sự khao khát hiểu biết của một học sinh. Dưới sự hướng dẫn của các ông thầy mới, tôi nhập vào cuộc nghiên cứu hòn đá phù thủy và trường sinh dược một cách cần mẫn nhất. Nhưng thuốc trường sinh chẳng mấy chốc thu hút toàn tâm toàn ý của tôi. Tiền của chỉ là vật hèn; nhưng khám phá của tôi sẽ được vinh diệu biết bao nếu như tôi trừ bỏ được bệnh tật khỏi cơ thể con người, làm con người miễn trừ với tất cả ngoài một cái chết dữ dội!

Ntate e ne e se saense, 'me ke ile ka siuoa ho loana le bofofu ba ngoana, ka eketsa lenyora la seithuti sa tsebo. en: She died calmly, and her countenance expressed affection even in death. I need not describe the feelings of those whose dearest ties are rent by that most irreparable evil, the void that presents itself to the soul, and the despair that is exhibited on the countenance. It is so long before the mind can persuade itself that she whom we saw every day and whose very existence appeared a part of our own can have departed for ever—that the brightness of a beloved eye can have been extinguished and the sound of a voice so familiar and dear to the ear can be hushed, never more to be heard. These are the reflections of the first days; but when the lapse of time proves the reality of the evil, then the actual bitterness of grief commences. Yet from whom has not that rude hand rent away some dear connection? And why should I describe a sorrow which all have felt, and must feel? The time at length arrives when grief is rather an indulgence than a necessity; and the smile that plays upon the lips, although it may be deemed a sacrilege, is not banished. My mother was dead, but we had still duties which we ought to perform; we must continue our course with the rest and learn to think ourselves fortunate whilst one remains whom the spoiler has not seized.

Phải mất bao lâu trí óc chúng tôi mới chấp nhận được là bà - người mà ngày nào chúng tôi cũng trông thấy, dường như đã là một phần của cuộc đời chúng tôi - lại có thể ra đi vĩnh viễn; ánh mắt sáng long lanh mà chúng tôi thương mến từ nay đã tắt hẳn; giọng nói quen thuộc quý yêu bên tai lại có thể bặt đi, không bao giờ còn vang lên. Những ngày đầu sau khi bà mất là như vậy đấy; nhưng khi thời gian trôi qua khẳng định đó là sự thật, nỗi đau xót thực sự mới bắt đầu. Thế nhưng đâu có ai chưa từng bị bàn tay phũ phàng kia dứt đi một mối duyên thân thiết? Và tôi cứ phải mô tả mãi làm gì nỗi đau mà ai cũng từng qua, và cũng phải qua? Cuối cùng cũng sẽ đến lúc đau thương là do buông thả thì đúng hơn là nhu cầu cần thiết, và nụ cười trên môi ta, dù có thể bị coi là báng bổ, không thể tắt bỏ hoàn toàn. Mẹ tôi đã mất, nhưng chúng tôi ai nấy đều có nhiệm vụ phải làm, phải đi theo con đường của mình cùng những người khác, tập suy nghĩ rằng mình may mắn khi còn chưa bị kẻ phá hoại cướp đi sinh mệnh.

es: Murió dulcemente; y su rostro aun en la muerte reflejaba su cariño. No necesito describir los sentimientos de aquellos cuyos lazos más queridos se ven rotos por el más irreparable de los males, el vacío que inunda el alma y la desesperación que embarga el rostro. Pasa tanto tiempo antes de que uno se pueda persuadir de que aquella a quien veíamos cada día, y cuya existencia misma formaba parte de la nuestra, ya no está con nosotros; que se ha extinguido la viveza de sus amados ojos y que su voz tan dulce y familiar se ha apagado para siempre. Estos son los pensamientos de los primeros días. Pero la amargura del dolor no comienza hasta que el transcurso del tiempo demuestra la realidad de la pérdida. ¿Pero a quién no le ha robado esa desconsiderada mano algún ser querido? ¿Por qué, pues, había de describir el dolor que todos han sentido y deberán sentir? Con el tiempo llega el momento en el que el sufrimiento es más una costumbre que una necesidad y, aunque parezca un sacrilegio, y a no se reprime la sonrisa que asoma a los labios. Mi madre había muerto, pero nosotros aún teníamos obligaciones que cumplir; debíamos continuar nuestro camino junto a los demás y considerarnos afortunados mientras quedara a salvo al menos uno de nosotros.

vi_translation: She passed away peacefully, even in death her face still showed affectionate love. I don't need to describe here the pain of those who have suffered an irreparable loss that has severed their closest emotional bonds; the emptiness left in each soul, and the sorrow etched on our faces. How long did it take for our minds to accept that she - the person we saw every day, who seemed to be a part of our lives - could leave us forever; the bright, sparkling eyes we loved were now completely extinguished; the familiar, beloved voice by our ears could be silent, never to be heard again. Those were the first days after she passed away; but as time confirmed the truth, the real pain began. But who has never had a close bond severed by that cruel hand? And why should I keep describing the pain that everyone has experienced, and must experience? Eventually, there will come a time when sorrow is more due to indulgence than necessity, and the smile on our lips, though it may be considered blasphemous, cannot be completely extinguished. My mother has passed away, but each of us has duties to fulfill, to follow our own paths with others, and to think that we are fortunate to have not yet had our lives taken by the destroyer.

tr_translation: My mother died in peace, even in death her face was full of compassion. I suppose there is no need for me to describe the feelings of those torn from their most precious bonds by an irreversible disaster, the void into which their souls fall, and the helplessness read on their faces. It takes such a long time to accept the idea that the person we see every day and embrace as part of our existence could leave us forever, that the sparkle in those beloved eyes could fade away, and that a voice so familiar and precious to our ears could fall silent, never to be heard again... These were my thoughts in the early days, but as time flowed and the reality of the disaster became apparent, the real pain also revealed itself. Yet, who among us has not had a very precious bond pulled and severed by that rough hand? And why should I attempt to describe a sorrow that everyone feels and should feel? Eventually, a time comes when sorrow turns from a necessity into a habit, and although it may seem disrespectful, the disappearance of the smile that lingers on the lips does not last forever. My mother had died, but we still had duties to fulfill. We had to continue on our path with everyone else and consider ourselves lucky as long as that spoilsport did not catch us.

es_translation: She died peacefully; and her face even in death reflected her affection. So much time passes before one can persuade oneself that she whom we saw every day, and whose very existence was part of ours, is no longer with us; that the liveliness of her beloved eyes has been extinguished and that her sweet and familiar voice has been silenced forever. These are the thoughts of the first days. But the bitterness of grief does not begin until the passage of time demonstrates the reality of the loss. But who has not had some loved one stolen by that inconsiderate hand? Why, then, should I describe the pain that everyone has felt and must feel? With time comes the moment when suffering is more a habit than a necessity and, although it may seem sacrilegious, the smile that appears on the lips is no longer suppressed. My mother had died, but we still had obligations to fulfill; we had to continue our path alongside others and consider ourselves fortunate as long as at least one of us remained safe.

st: O ile a shoa ka khutso, 'me sefahleho sa hae se ile sa bontša lerato la hae esita le lefung. Ha ke hloke ho hlalosa maikutlo a bao maqhama a bona a ratehang a hiriloeng ke bobe boo boholo bo ke keng ba lekanngoa, sekheo se itlhahisang moeeng, le ho nyahama ho bonts'itsoeng ho sefahleho. Ke nako e telele haholo pele kelello e khona ho itlhahisa hore eena eo re mo boneng letsatsi le leng le le leng mme eo boteng ba hae bo hlahileng karolo ea bona e ka be e le karolo ea rona e ka 'nang ea tloha ka nako e sa lekanyetsoang,' me khanya ea leihlo le ratoang e ka be e tima mme molumo oa lentsoe le tloaetseng mme o ratehang tsebeng e ka huloa,  Le ka mohla u se ke ua hlola u utloa. Mona ke lintlha tsa matsatsi a pele a ho qetela; Empa ha nako ea ho fela ha nako e ntse e le teng e paka hore bobe bo teng, joale bohloko ba 'nete bo qala. Empa ke mang ea e-s'o ka e-ba le bothata ba ho etsa hore ho be le kamano e ntle? Hona ke hobane'ng ha ke lokela ho hlalosa masoabi eo bohle ba ileng ba ikutloa ba e-na le maikutlo a bona' me ba lokela ho ikutloa? nako e telele e fihla ha ho malimabe ho e-na le ho hloka ho hloka; Mme pososelo e bapalang molomong, leha e ka nkuoa e le sacrilege, ha e tsoe. 'Mè oa ka o ne a shoele, empa re ne re sa ntse re na le mesebetsi eo re lokelang ho e etsa. Re tlameha ho tsoelapele ka thuto ea rona le tse ling kaofela mme re ithute ho nahana ka lehlohonolo ha motho a ntse a lula eo spoiler e sa kang ea e nka.
yo: Ó kú pẹ̀lú ìrọ̀rùn, ojú rẹ̀ sì fi ìfẹ́ hàn kódà nínú ikú. Mi ò nílò láti ṣàpèjúwe ìmọ̀lára àwọn tí àjọṣepọ̀ ọ̀wọ́n wọn jẹ́ ìyálò nípasẹ̀ ibi tí kò ṣe é ṣe, àlàfo tí ó fi ara rẹ̀ hàn sí ọkàn, àti ìrètí tí wọ́n ṣe àfihàn rẹ̀ lórí ìrísí. Ó ti pẹ́ kí ọkàn tó lè rọ ara rẹ̀ pé òun tí a rí lójoojúmọ́ tí ìwàláàyè rẹ̀ sì jọ ara wa lè ti lọ títí láéláé - pé ìmọ́lẹ̀ ojú olólùfẹ́ lè ti parun àti ohùn ohùn tí ó mọ̀ dáadáa tí ó sì nífẹ̀ẹ́ etí lè dákẹ́,  má ṣe gbọ́ ọ mọ́ láéláé. Awọn wọnyi ni awọn iṣaro ti awọn ọjọ akọkọ; Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tí àkókò bá fi òtítọ́ ìwà búburú hàn, nígbà náà ìkorò ìbànújẹ́ bẹ̀rẹ̀. Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ ta ni ọwọ́ ìkà yẹn kò yá àwọn ìsopọ̀ ọ̀wọ́n kan? Kí ló dé tí mo fi gbọ́dọ̀ ṣàpèjúwe ìbànújẹ́ tí gbogbo wọn ti ní ìmọ̀lára, tí ó sì gbọ́dọ̀ ní ìmọ̀lára? Akoko gigun de nigbati ibanujẹ jẹ dipo indulgence ju iwulo lọ; Àti ẹ̀rín tí ó ń ṣeré lórí ètè, bí ó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé a lè kà á sí sacrilege, ni a kò lé e kúrò. Ìyá mi ti kú, ṣùgbọ́n a ṣì ní àwọn iṣẹ́ tí ó yẹ kí a ṣe; A gbọ́dọ̀ tẹ̀síwájú nínú ọ̀nà wa pẹ̀lú àwọn yòókù kí a sì kọ́ bí a ṣe ń rò ara wa ní oríire nígbà tí ẹnìkan ṣì jẹ́ ẹni tí olùbàjẹ́ náà kò gbà.
tn: Le fa go ntse jalo, o ne a ikutlwa a ritibetse e bile o ne a bontsha lorato lwa gagwe tota le fa a swa. Ga ke tlhoke go tlhalosa maikutlo a batho ba ba ratang go gaisa ba ba hirilweng ke bosula jo bo sa itshwarelweng, selo se se sa siamang se se bontshang gore moya o o se nang molato, le go felelwa ke tshepo e e bontshang gore o a bo a le mo maemong a a kwa tlase. 12 Ke ka ntlha yang fa motho a ka bona sengwe le sengwe se re se bonyeng letsatsi le letsatsi, mme yo go bonalang e le karolo ya gagwe e e neng e le ya gagwe e e neng e le ya go nna teng ga rona, a ka bo a sa ntse a le gaufi le go huduga, mme go ka bo go na le modumo o o ratiwang,  Ga nkitla ke tlhola ke utlwa selo se se botoka. 12Ke tsona tse di tla dirafalang tsa malatsi a bofelo; Le fa go ntse jalo, fa nako e ntse e tsamaya, dilo tse di bosula di a fela, di tla bo di sa ntse di le teng. Mme gone, ke mang yo o sa kang a nna le kamano e e ntseng jalo e e sa tshwanelang go nna le kamano e e sa tshwanelang? Ke ka ntlha yang fa ke tshwanetse go bontsha khutsafalo e e botlhoko e batho botlhe ba ileng ba e utlwa e bile ba tshwanetse go ikutlwa jang? 11 Go na le moo, fa motho a le mo kutlobotlhokong, go na le go nna le go tlhoka gore a se ka a se tlhoka; Le fa go ntse jalo, monyenyo o o ka tswang o le monyenyo o o ka tswang o tsewa o le molato, ga o ka ke wa lelekwa. Re ne re sa ntse re na le tiro e re neng re tshwanetse go e dira. Re tshwanetse go tswelela re le mo tseleng e e setseng, mme re ithute go akanya gore re na le lesego fa re sa ntse re le mo go lone.
ty: Ua pohe oia ma te hau, e ua faaite to ' na hoho'a mata i te here e tae noa ' tu i te pohe. Aita e faufaa na'u ia faataa'tu i te mau mana'o o te feia tei roohia i te ati na roto i taua ino rahi ra, te mana'o faufaa ore e vai nei i roto i te varua, e te hepohepo e itehia nei i ni'a i te hoho'a mata. E mea maoro roa i roto i te feruriraa e nehenehe ai i te feruriraa ia haapapû ia'na iho e te taata ta tatou i ite i te mau mahana atoa e o tei riro ei tuhaa no to tatou iho oraraa e a muri noa'tu—e nehenehe te anaana o te hoê mata here e pohe e e faaroohia te ta'i o te hoê reo tei matau-maitai-hia e tei herehia e te tari'a,  eita e faaroo-faahou-hia. E mau faaiteraa teie no te mau mahana matamua ; ia ore ana'e râ te tau e haapapu i te tupuraa mau o te ino, i reira ïa te inoino mau o te oto e haamata ' i. Teie râ, aita teie rima ino i faaore i te tahi taairaa here? E no te aha e ti'a'i ia'u ia faaite atu i te hoê oto tei fariihia e te taatoaraa, e e ti'a ia'u ia ite ? Te tae mai nei te taime e riro ai te oto ei mea hau atu i te hoê mea titau-noa-hia ; e te mata ataata i ni'a i te utu, noa'tu e, e hi'oraa ha'iha'i roa ïa. Ua pohe to'u metua vahine, tera râ, te vai noa ra â te tahi mau ohipa e ti'a ia matou ia rave; e ti'a ia tatou ia tamau noa i to tatou haere'a e te toe'a e ia haapii i te mana'o e e mea fana'o tatou i te mea ta te taata hamani ino i ore i haru.

mai: ओ शान्तिसँ मरि गेलीह, आ हुनक मुँह मृत्युमे सेहो स्नेह व्यक्त कयलक। हमरा ओहि लोकक भावनाक वर्णन करबाक आवश्यकता नहि अछि जिनकर प्रियतम सम्बन्ध ओहि सबसँ अपूरणीय बुराईसँ भरल अछि, ओ शून्य जे आत्माक समक्ष प्रस्तुत करैत अछि, आ ओहि निराशाक वर्णन करबाक जे मुँह पर प्रदर्शित होइत अछि। एतेक दिन भऽ गेल अछि जे मन अपनाकेँ मना सकैत अछि जे ओ जकरा हम सभ दिन देखलहुँ आ जकर अस्तित्व हमरासभक अपन अंग देखाइत छल, सदाक लेल चलि गेल होयत – जे प्रिय आँखिक चमक बुझि गेल होयत आ कानकेँ एतेक परिचित आ प्रिय आवाजक ध्वनि दबा देल जा सकैत अछि।  कखनहु बेसी नहि सुनल जाए। ई पहिल दिनक प्रतिबिंब अछि। मुदा जखन समयक बीतनाइ बुराईक वास्तविकताकेँ सिद्ध करैत अछि, तखन शोकक वास्तविक कड़वाहट शुरू भऽ जाइत अछि। तइयो ओ असभ्य हाथ केकरा सँ किछु प्रिय संबंध नहि छीन लेलक? आ हम एकटा एहन दुखक वर्णन किएक करब जे सभ अनुभव कयने छथि, आ जरूर अनुभव करबाक चाही? लम्बा समय अबैत अछि जखन शोक आवश्यकतासँ बेसी भोग होइत अछि; आ जे मुस्कान ओठ पर बजैत अछि, यद्यपि एकरा अपवित्रता मानल जा सकैत अछि, ओकरा निर्वासित नहि कयल जाइत अछि। हमर माय मरि गेल छलीह, मुदा हमरा लग एखनो कर्तव्य छल जे हमरा पूरा करबाक चाही; हमरासभकेँ बाकीक सङ्ग अपन मार्ग जारी रखबाक चाही आ अपनाकेँ भाग्यशाली मानब सीखबाक चाही जखन कि एकटा एहन रहैत अछि जकरा बिगाड़निहार नहि पकड़ने अछि।
mg: Maty tamim - pahatoniana izy, ary naneho firaiketam - po ny endriny, na dia tamin'ny fahafatesana aza. Tsy mila mamaritra ny fihetseham-pon'ireo izay manana fifandraisana sarobidy indrindra nofafàna tamin'ny alalan'izany faharatsiana tsy azo sarahina izany aho, ny fahabangana izay miseho amin'ny fanahy, ary ny fahadisoam-panantenana izay aseho eo amin'ny tarehy. Ela loatra vao afaka mandresy lahatra ny tenany ny saina hany ka ilay olona izay hitantsika isan'andro sy ny fisiany mihitsy no afaka ho lasa mandrakizay—ka mety ho maty ny famirapiratan'ny maso malala iray ary ny feon'ny feo iray izay efa mahazatra sy malala eo amin'ny sofina dia mety ho voageja,  Tsy ho re intsony izany. Ireo no taratry ny andro voalohany; Fa rehefa hita anefa fa tena misy ny faharatsiana, dia manomboka ny alahelo tena izy. Kanefa avy amin'iza moa izany tanana tsy mahalala fomba izany no nampikatso ny fifandraisana tsy misy dikany? Ary nahoana aho no tokony hamaritra ny alahelo izay tsapan'ny rehetra, ary tsy maintsy tsapako? Tonga ny fotoana maharitra rehefa ny alahelo dia somary fanaranam-po fa tsy zavatra ilaina; Ary ny tsiky izay milalao eo amin'ny molotra, na dia azo heverina ho sorona, dia tsy nandroaka. Maty ny reniko, saingy mbola nanana adidy izay tokony ho tanterahanay izahay; Tsy maintsy manohy ny diantsika miaraka amin'ny hafa isika ary mianatra mieritreritra ny tenantsika ho tsara vintana raha mbola misy olona iray izay tsy nalain'ilay mpanimba.

en: The summer months passed while I was thus engaged, heart and soul, in one pursuit. It was a most beautiful season; never did the fields bestow a more plentiful harvest or the vines yield a more luxuriant vintage, but my eyes were insensible to the charms of nature. And the same feelings which made me neglect the scenes around me caused me also to forget those friends who were so many miles absent, and whom I had not seen for so long a time. I knew my silence disquieted them, and I well remembered the words of my father: “I know that while you are pleased with yourself you will think of us with affection, and we shall hear regularly from you. You must pardon me if I regard any interruption in your correspondence as a proof that your other duties are equally neglected.”

vi_translation: The summer months passed by while I was still engrossed in work, wholeheartedly dedicated. This is the most beautiful season of the year, the rice fields have never signaled a better harvest, and the vineyards also promise a bountiful yield, yet my eyes are completely indifferent to the beauty of nature. Just as I am indifferent to the scenery around me, I also completely forget my friends in the distant, inaccessible homeland, whom I haven't seen for a long time. I know my silence makes them anxious, and I deeply miss my father's advice: “I know that while enjoying life, you still think of us with affectionate love, and the house will often receive your letters. You cannot blame me if I consider your neglect of correspondence as a sign that you are neglecting all your other duties as well.”

The feelings that caused me to ignore the scenery surrounding me also made me forget my friends who were miles away and whom I hadn't seen for a long time. I knew that my silence worried them, and I remembered my father's words very well: "We already know that when you are content, you will remember us with love and that we will receive regular news from you. Ke ne ka simolola go utlwa mafoko a ga Rre a ne a re: "Ke itse gore fa o sa ntse o itumedisitse, o tla akanya ka rona ka lorato, e bile re tla utlwa go tswa mo go wena. I felt that emotions like joy and compassion were being rekindled within me. My pessimism had vanished, and I quickly returned to the cheerfulness I had before succumbing to my deadly obsession.
tr_translation_results:

* The mention of the changing seasons and the protagonist's emotional state also resonates with the themes of alienation and absurdity present in the book.
* The writing style and tone of the passage seem to match Camus's distinctive literary voice.
es_translation: Very slowly, and with numerous relapses that worried and saddened my friend, I recovered. I remember that the first time I could focus on the objects around me with a hint of pleasure, I noticed that the dead leaves had disappeared, and tender shoots covered the trees that shaded my window. It was a delightful spring, and the season greatly contributed to my improvement. I felt feelings of affection and joy reborn in me; my sorrow disappeared, and soon I regained the liveliness I had before succumbing to my horrible obsession.

en: Where had they fled when the next morning I awoke? All of soul-inspiriting fled with sleep, and dark melancholy clouded every thought. The rain was pouring in torrents, and thick mists hid the summits of the mountains, so that I even saw not the faces of those mighty friends. Still I would penetrate their misty veil and seek them in their cloudy retreats. What were rain and storm to me? My mule was brought to the door, and I resolved to ascend to the summit of Montanvert. I remembered the effect that the view of the tremendous and ever-moving glacier had produced upon my mind when I first saw it. It had then filled me with a sublime ecstasy that gave wings to the soul and allowed it to soar from the obscure world to light and joy. The sight of the awful and majestic in nature had indeed always the effect of solemnising my mind and causing me to forget the passing cares of life. I determined to go without a guide, for I was well acquainted with the path, and the presence of another would destroy the solitary grandeur of the scene.

vi: Chúng đã biến hết đi đâu khi tôi tỉnh dậy sáng hôm sau? Giấc ngủ trôi qua, mọi thứ truyền cho tâm hồn tôi sức sống cũng trôi theo nốt, nỗi u sầu tăm tối lại che phủ mọi ý nghĩ của tôi. Mưa rơi xối xả, sương mù dày đặc che khuất những ngọn núi, thậm chí tôi còn không nhìn được gương mặt những người bạn hùng mạnh của tôi. Thế nhưng tôi vẫn muốn xuyên qua tấm mạng sương mù đó, đi tìm họ về tận chốn trú ẩn giăng mây của họ. Mưa bão đối với tôi nghĩa lý gì? Con la đã được đem đến trước cửa, tôi quyết định sẽ lên tận đỉnh núi Montanvert. Tôi còn nhớ ấn tượng lần đầu trông thấy trên núi mặt biển băng lớn mênh mông và không ngừng di chuyển. Lúc đó tôi đã có một cảm giác say sưa cao cả đến tuyệt vời khiến tâm hồn tôi cất cánh bay bổng khỏi chốn trần tục tối tăm lên nơi chỉ có niềm vui và ánh sáng. Cảnh tượng thiên nhiên oai nghiêm đến dễ sợ bao giờ cũng làm trí não tôi trang nghiêm trở lại, quên đi những lo toan thoáng qua của đời thường. Tôi quyết định leo núi không cần người hướng dẫn, bởi tôi đã quen thuộc con đường, hơn nữa có mặt thêm một người khác sẽ làm khung cảnh bớt đi vẻ huy hoàng cô độc.

tr: Sabah uyandığımda neredeydiler acaba? Ruhumu canlandıranların hepsi uykuyla birlikte kayıplara karışmıştı ve kapkara melankoli tüm düşüncelerimi gölgelemeye başlamıştı. Bardaktan boşanırcasına yağmur yağıyordu ve kalın bir sis, dağların zirvelerini sarmıştı. Böylece o kudretli dostların çehrelerini de göremez oldum. Yine de pustan peçelerine nüfuz edebilir, onları dumanlı sığınaklarında arayabilirdim. Yağmur, fırtına da neymiş? Katırım kapıya getirildi ve Montanvert'in zirvesine tırmanmaya karar verdim. Devasa, sürekli hareket eden buzulu ilk görüşümün zihnimde yarattığı etkiyi hatırladım. Ruhu kanatlandırarak meçhul bir dünyadan aydınlığa ve sevince doğru taşıyan yüce bir coşku doldurmuştu içimi. Doğadaki o heybet ve azamet oldum olası zihnimi yatıştırmış, hayatın gelip geçici dertlerini unutmamı sağlamıştı. Yolu iyi bildiğimden ve başka birinin varlığı manzaranın ıssız ihtişamını bozacağından rehbersiz gitmeye karar verdim.

es: —Querido primo —me dijo—, ¿ves cuánta felicidad contagias cuando estás alegre? ¡No recaigas de nuevo! La mañana siguiente amaneció con una lluvia torrencial, y una espesa niebla ocultaba las cimas de las montañas. Me levanté temprano, pero me sentía melancólico. La lluvia me deprimía; volvió mi acostumbrado estado de ánimo, y me sentí apesadumbrado. Sabía lo que este cambio brusco apenaría a mi padre y preferí evitarlo, hasta haberme recobrado lo suficiente como para poder disimular estos sentimientos que me dominaban. Supuse que pasarían el día en el albergue, y dado que yo estaba acostumbrado a la lluvia, la humedad y el frío, decidí ir solo a la cima del Montanvert[58]. Recordaba la impresión que el inmenso glaciar en constante movimiento me había causado la primera vez que lo vi. Entonces me había llenado de un éxtasis que prestaba alas al espíritu, permitiéndole despegarse del mundo de tinieblas y remontarse hasta la luz y la felicidad. La contemplación de todo lo que de majestuoso y sobrecogedor hay en la naturaleza siempre ha tenido la virtud de ennoblecer mis sentimientos y me ha hecho olvidar las efímeras preocupaciones de la vida. Decidí ir solo, pues conocía bien el camino, y la presencia de otro hubiera destruido la grandiosa soledad del paraje.

vi_translation: Where had they all gone when I woke up the next morning? As sleep passed, everything that had given my soul vitality also drifted away, and the dark melancholy once again shrouded all my thoughts. The rain poured down, and thick fog obscured the mountains; I couldn't even see the faces of my mighty friends. Yet I still wanted to pierce through that veil of fog, to seek them out in their cloud-shrouded refuge. What did the storm mean to me? The mule had been brought to the door, and I decided to ascend to the summit of Montanvert. I still remember the impression of first seeing the vast, ever-moving sea of ice on the mountain. At that moment, I felt a sublime exhilaration that lifted my soul from the dark earthly realm to a place of pure joy and light. The awe-inspiring and fearsome spectacle of nature always restored a sense of solemnity to my mind, making me forget the fleeting worries of everyday life. I decided to climb the mountain without a guide, as I was familiar with the path, and having another person present would diminish the solitary grandeur of the scene.

tr_translation: I wonder where they were when I woke up in the morning? All those who invigorated my soul had vanished with sleep, and pitch-black melancholy had begun to overshadow all my thoughts. It was raining cats and dogs, and a thick fog had enveloped the mountain peaks. Thus, I could no longer see the faces of those mighty friends. Still, I could penetrate their veils of mist and search for them in their smoky shelters. What was rain or storm? My mule was brought to the door, and I decided to climb to the summit of Montanvert. I remembered the impact on my mind of my first sight of the gigantic, ever-moving glacier. A sublime enthusiasm had filled me, lifting my spirit and carrying it from an unknown world to light and joy. The grandeur and majesty in nature had always soothed my mind, making me forget the fleeting troubles of life. Since I knew the path well and another person's presence would spoil the desolate splendor of the scenery, I decided to go without a guide.

es_translation: —Dear cousin —he said to me—, do you see how much happiness you spread when you are cheerful? Don't relapse again! The next morning dawned with a torrential rain, and a thick fog obscured the mountain peaks. I got up early, but I felt melancholic. The rain depressed me; my usual state of mind returned, and I felt sorrowful. I knew that this sudden change would sadden my father and I preferred to avoid it until I had recovered enough to be able to hide these feelings that dominated me. I assumed they would spend the day at the lodge, and since I was used to the rain, humidity, and cold, I decided to go alone to the top of Montanvert[58]. I remembered the impression that the immense, constantly moving glacier had made on me the first time I saw it. Then I had been filled with an ecstasy that lent wings to the spirit, allowing it to detach from the world of darkness and soar towards light and happiness. The contemplation of all that is majestic and awe-inspiring in nature has always had the virtue of ennobling my feelings and has made me forget the ephemeral worries of life. I decided to go alone, for I knew the way well, and the presence of another would have destroyed the grand solitude of the place.

st: O ne o le kae ha ke tsoha hoseng? Kaofela ha moea-inspiriting o ile a baleha ka boroko, 'me melancholy e lefifi e ile ea fifala monahano o mong le o mong. Pula e ne e tšollela molapo o phoroselang, 'me moholi o teteaneng o pata likopano tsa lithaba, hoo ke bileng ke sa bone lifahleho tsa metsoalle eo e matla. Ke ne ke ntse ke tla phunyeletsa lesira la bona le letšoha 'me ke li batla ka har'a li-fleas tsa bona. Ke ne ke na le pula le sefefo sefe ho 'na? Mohapi oa ka o ile oa tlisoa monyako, 'me ke ile ka etsa qeto ea ho nyolohela tlhōrōng ea Montanvert. Ke hopola phello ea hore pono ea leqhoa le neng le le neng le tsamaea le ne le hlahisoa kelellong ea ka ha ke qala ho e bona. Ka mor'a moo, e ne e tletse ka ecstasy e kafukafu e ileng ea fana ka mapheo ho moea 'me a lumella hore e hōle ho tloha lefatšeng le sa hlakang ho ea leseling le thabo. Pono ea tlhaho e tšabehang le e hlomphehang ka tlhaho e ne e hlile e na le phello ea ho matlafatsa kelello ea ka le ho etsa hore ke lebale tlhokomelo e fetang ea bophelo. Ke ile ka etsa qeto ea ho ea ntle le motataisi, hobane ke ne ke tseba hantle tsela, 'me boteng ba e mong bo tla senya moholo o le mong oa sebaka seo.
yo: Níbo ni wọ́n sá lọ nígbà tí mo jí ní àárọ̀ ọjọ́ kejì? Gbogbo ọkàn-inspiriting sá pẹ̀lú oorun, ìbànújẹ́ dúdú sì kún fún gbogbo èrò. Òjò ń rọ̀ ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ omi, àwọn ìkùukùu tí ó nípọn sì fi àwọn òkè ńlá pamọ́, kí n má baà rí ojú àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ alágbára wọ̀nyẹn. Síbẹ̀ mà á wọ ìbòjú ìkùukùu wọn mà á sì wá wọn ní àwọn ibi ìsinmi àwọsánmọ̀ wọn. Kí ni òjò àti ìjì líle sí mi? Wọ́n mú ẹlẹ́rìndòdò mi wá sí ìlẹ̀kùn, mo sì pinnu láti gòkè lọ sí òkè Montanvert. Mo rántí ipa tí ìwòye yìnyín ńlá tí ó sì ń rìn ti ṣe lọ́kàn mi nígbà tí mo kọ́kọ́ rí i. Lẹ́yìn náà ó ti kún mi pẹ̀lú ìdùnnú ńlá tí ó fún ọkàn ní ìyẹ́ tí ó sì jẹ́ kí ó fò láti ayé tí kò mọ̀ sí ìmọ́lẹ̀ àti ayọ̀. Ìrírí burúkú àti ọlá nínú ìṣẹ̀dá ní tòótọ́ ipa ìfọkànsìn ọkàn mi àti mímú kí n gbàgbé àwọn ìtọ́jú ìgbésí ayé tó ń kọjá. Mo pinnu láti lọ láìsí ìtọ́sọ́nà, nítorí mo mọ ọ̀nà náà dáadáa, wíwà ẹlòmíràn yóò sì ba ọlá ìran náà jẹ́.
tn: O ne a le kae fa ke ne ke tsamaya mo mosong? Batho botlhe ba ba neng ba robetse ba ne ba robala, mme ba ne ba le mo lefifing ba ne ba ritibala mo mogopolong mongwe le mongwe. Dipula tsa ne tsa tsholola mo meeding, mme megopo e e mebe e e iphitlhile kwa dithabeng, mo ke bileng ke sa bone difatlhego tsa ditsala tse di thata tseo. Ke ne ke sa ntse ke batlana le bone ba ba neng ba le mo go yone, ke ba kopa gore ba se ka ba tlhola ba le mo mefagong ya bone. Ke eng se se neng sa dira gore ke ne ke na le pula le matsubutsubu? Ke ne ka isiwa kwa kgorong, mme ke ne ka swetsa ka gore ke ye go ya kwa Kopanong ya Montanvert. Ke ne ka lemoga gore go ne go na le tsela e ke neng ke leba dilo ka yone fa ke ne ke simolola go akanya ka yone fa ke ne ke simolola go e bona. E ne ya re morago ga moo e ne ya dira gore ke nne le moya o o sa boneng go tswa mo lefatsheng le le lefifi go ya kwa leseding le boitumelo. Ka dinako tse dingwe go ne go na le dilo tse di bosula tse ke neng ke di dira e bile di dira gore ke se ka nna le diphelelo tse di molemo tsa go akanya ka botshelo jwa me. Ke ne ka swetsa ka gore ke se ka ya ka kaelo, gonne ke ne ke itse sentle ka tsela e e molemo, mme yo mongwe o tla senya mogolo yo o esi wa lefelo leo.
ty: Ihea to ratou hororaa i to ' u araraa mai i te poipoi a'e? Ua horo ê te mau mana'o atoa no ni'a i te taoto, e ua tapo'i te poiri i te mau mana'o atoa. Ua topa maira te ûa, e ua tapo'i ihora te mau ata meumeu i te mau tupuai mou'a, e aita ' tura vau i ite i te mata o taua mau hoa puai ra. Noa ' tu râ, e tomo atu vau i roto i to ratou paruru rupehu e e imi au ia ratou i roto i ta ratou mau hororaa ata. Eaha te ûa e te vero i nia ia ' u? Ua afaihia to ' u asini i te uputa, e ua opua ' tura vau e paiuma i nia i te tupuai mou'a no Montanvert. Ua haamana'o a'era vau i te mea ta te hi'oraa o te pape paari rahi e te puai i faatupu i roto i to'u feruriraa i te taime matamua a ite ai au i te reira. Ua faaî te reira ia'u i te maere rahi o tei horo'a i te varua i te mana'o e ua ti'a ia'u ia rere mai te ao poiri i te maramarama e te oaoa. I to ' u iteraa ' tu i te mea riaria e te hanahana o te natura, ua turai noa te reira i to ' u feruriraa e ua turai te reira ia ' u ia haamoe i te mau fifi o te oraraa. Ua faaoti a'era vau e haere ma te arata'i ore, i te mea e, ua ite maitai au i te e'a, e na te taeraa mai o te tahi atu taata e haamou i te ti'araa hanahana o te reira ohipa.

mai: अगिला दिन भोर मे जखन हम जागि गेलहुं तखन ओ कतए भागि गेल छलाह? सब आत्मा-उत्साही निद्रा सँ भागि गेल, आ अन्हार उदासी हर विचार के बादल बना देलक। बरखा मूसलाधार बहैत छल, आ मोटगर धुंध पहाड़क शिखरकेँ नुका देलक, जाहिसँ हम ओहि पराक्रमी मित्रक चेहरा सेहो नहि देखलहुँ। तइयो हम हुनकर धुंधला घूंघट मे घुसि जाइत छलहुं आ हुनका लोकनिक बादल भरल पाछू हटय मे तकैत छलहुं। हमरा लेल बरखा आ तूफान की छल? हमर खच्चरकेँ दरवाजापर आनल गेल, आ हम मोंटानवर्टक शिखर पर चढ़बाक संकल्प लेलहुँ। हमरा ओ प्रभाव मोन पड़ल जे जबरदस्त आ सदिखन चलैत ग्लेशियरक दृश्य हमरा दिमाग पर उत्पन्न कयलक जखन हम एकरा पहिल बेर देखलहुँ। तखन ई हमरा एकटा उदात्त परमानन्दसँ भरि देलक जे आत्माकेँ पँख देलक आ एकरा अस्पष्ट दुनियासँ प्रकाश आ आनन्द दिस उड़बाक अनुमति देलक। प्रकृतिमे भयानक आ राजसी लोकनिक दृष्टि वास्तवमे सदैव हमर मनकेँ पवित्र करबाक आ जीवनक गुजरैत चिन्ताकेँ बिसरि जयबाक प्रभाव पड़ैत छल। हम बिना मार्गदर्शकक जयबाक निश्चय कयलहुँ, किएक तँ हम मार्गसँ नीक जकाँ परिचित छलहुँ, आ दोसर गोटेक उपस्थिति दृश्यक एकान्त भव्यताकेँ नष्ट कऽ देत।
mg: Taiza no nandosiran'izy ireo rehefa nifoha aho ny ampitso maraina? Nandositra tamin'ny torimaso avokoa ny fanahy rehetra, ary rahona maizina ny eritreritra rehetra. Ary nirotsaka ny ranonorana tamin'ny riaka, ary nisy zavona matevina nanafina ny tampon'ny tendrombohitra, ka dia tsy nahita ny tavan'ireo namana mahery ireo aho. Mbola hiditra ao anatin'ny voalin'izy ireo ihany aho ary hitady azy ireo ao anatin'ny fihemoran'izy ireo feno rahona. Inona no nataon'ny orana sy ny tafio-drivotra tamiko? Nentina teo am - baravarana ny ampondrako, ary tapa - kevitra ny hiakatra any an - tampon'i Montanvert aho. Tsaroako ny fiantraikan'ny fomba fijerin'ilay vongan-dranomandry goavana sy tsy mitsaha-mitombo tao an-tsaiko tamin'ny fotoana nahitako azy voalohany. Avy eo dia nameno ahy tamin'ny fifaliana faran'izay tsara izany izay nanome elatra ho an'ny fanahy ary namela azy hiakatra avy amin'ny tontolo tsy mazava ho amin'ny fahazavana sy ny fifaliana. Ny fahitana ny zava-mahatsiravina sy ny voninahitra eo amin'ny natiora dia tena nisy foana ny fiantraikan'ny fanamasinana ny saiko sy ny nahatonga ahy hanadino ireo fiahiana mandalo eo amin'ny fiainana. Nanapa-kevitra ny handeha tsy nisy mpitarika aho, satria nahafantatra tsara ny lalana aho ary ny fanatrehan'ny olona iray hafa dia handrava ilay halehiben'ny toerana irery teo amin'ilay toerana.

en: “I expected this reception,” said the dæmon. “All men hate the wretched; how, then, must I be hated, who am miserable beyond all living things! Yet you, my creator, detest and spurn me, thy creature, to whom thou art bound by ties only dissoluble by the annihilation of one of us. You purpose to kill me. How dare you sport thus with life? Do your duty towards me, and I will do mine towards you and the rest of mankind. If you will comply with my conditions, I will leave them and you at peace; but if you refuse, I will glut the maw of death, until it be satiated with the blood of your remaining friends.”

en: “Being thus provided, I resolved to reside in this hovel until something should occur which might alter my determination. It was indeed a paradise compared to the bleak forest, my former residence, the rain-dropping branches, and dank earth. I ate my breakfast with pleasure and was about to remove a plank to procure myself a little water when I heard a step, and looking through a small chink, I beheld a young creature, with a pail on her head, passing before my hovel. The girl was young and of gentle demeanour, unlike what I have since found cottagers and farmhouse servants to be. Yet she was meanly dressed, a coarse blue petticoat and a linen jacket being her only garb; her fair hair was plaited but not adorned: she looked patient yet sad. I lost sight of her, and in about a quarter of an hour she returned bearing the pail, which was now partly filled with milk. As she walked along, seemingly incommoded by the burden, a young man met her, whose countenance expressed a deeper despondence. Uttering a few sounds with an air of melancholy, he took the pail from her head and bore it to the cottage himself. She followed, and they disappeared. Presently I saw the young man again, with some tools in his hand, cross the field behind the cottage; and the girl was also busied, sometimes in the house and sometimes in the yard.

Nơi đây quả thật thiên đường, so với rừng thẳm nơi ở cũ của tôi, nền là đất ẩm, trên đầu thì mưa rỏ xuống từ cành lá. Tôi ăn bữa sáng đầy mãn nguyện, và định dỡ một tấm ván để lấy nước uống thì nghe có tiếng bước chân; và nhìn qua kẽ hở tôi thấy một sinh vật nhỏ đi qua cái ổ của mình, đầu đội cái xô. Cô gái còn rất trẻ, dáng điệu yêu kiều, khác hẳn đám nông dân và người ở trong trang trại mà sau này tôi gặp. Tuy thế cô mặc rất nghèo nàn, trang phục chỉ có mỗi chiếc váy lót thô màu xanh với một áo ngắn bằng len; mái tóc sáng được tết thành bím, nhưng chẳng tô điểm kiểu cách gì; trông cô điềm đạm nhưng buồn bã. Cô đi khỏi tầm mắt tôi, nhưng mười lăm phút sau quay lại, mang theo cái xô đầy lưng sữa, có vẻ khó khăn. Vừa lúc đó một anh thanh niên xuất hiện, nét mặt còn biểu lộ nỗi chán nản sâu xa hơn. Thốt ra vài tiếng nghe ai oán, anh nhấc xô sữa trên đầu cô gái rồi tự mình mang vào nhà. Cô gái đi theo, cả hai mất hút. Sau đó tôi lại trông thấy chàng trai, tay cầm mấy thứ dụng cụ gì đó, đi băng qua cánh đồng sau nhà cô gái cũng tất bật làm việc, lúc thì trong nhà, lúc thì ngoài sân.

tr: İhtiyaçlarımı bu şekilde karşılayınca, kararımı değiştirecek herhangi bir şey olana kadar bu ağılda kalmaya karar verdim. Burası eski yurdum olan kasvetli ormana, yağmur sızdıran dallara ve ıslak toprağa kıyasla gerçekten de cennet gibiydi. Kahvaltımı keyifle etmiş, biraz su alabilmek için bir kütüğü kaldırmak üzereydim ki ayak sesleri duydum. Küçük bir oyuktan bakınca başının üstünde kova taşıyan bir kızın ağılımın yanından geçtiğini gördüm. Bu gencecik bir kızdı ve o âna kadar gördüğüm köylüler ile çiftlik evindeki hizmetçilerden farklı olarak çok nazik görünümlüydü. Ancak kıyafeti kaba sabaydı; kötü bir kumaştan mavi bir etek, keten bir ceketten başka bir şey yoktu üstünde. San saçları örgülü, ama sadeydi. Metanetli, ama üzgün bir hali vardı. Derken gözden kayboldu, fakat on beş dakika kadar sonra, bu kez yansına kadar sütle doldurulmuş kovayla yeniden ortaya çıktı. Yükünü besbelli güçlükle taşıyarak yürüdüğü sırada karşısına, yüzünde daha da karamsar bir ifade olan genç bir adam çıktı. Genç adam, dertli dertli iki çift laf ettikten sonra kovayı kızın elinden alarak, kulübeye kendisi taşıdı. Kız da peşinden gitti ve gözden kayboldular. Delikanlı birazdan elinde alet edevatla yine ortaya çıktı ve kulübenin ardındaki tarlayı boydan boya geçti. Kız da kimi zaman ev, kimi zaman da bahçe işleriyle meşgul oluyordu.

es: Así provisto, me dispuse a permanecer en esta choza hasta que ocurriera algo que modificara mi decisión. Comparada con mi anterior morada, el desangelado bosque donde las ramas goteaban lluvia y el suelo estaba mojado, era en verdad un paraíso. Desayuné con fruición, y me disponía a levantar un madero para sacar agua cuando escuché pasos y vi, por una rendija, a una muchacha que, balanceando un cubo en la cabeza, pasaba por delante de mi cobertizo. Era joven y de aspecto dulce, distinta de lo que más tarde he comprobado que son los labriegos y los criados de las granjas. Iba vestida humildemente, con una tosca falda azul y una chaqueta de paño. Sus cabellos rubios estaban trenzados pero no llevaba adornos. Sus facciones revelaban resignación, pero su aspecto era triste. La perdí de vista, pero transcurridos unos quince minutos reapareció con el mismo recipiente, que ahora estaba medio lleno de leche. Mientras andaba, claramente incómoda por el peso, un joven de rostro aún más deprimido se dirigió a su encuentro. Con aire melancólico intercambiaron algunas palabras, y cogiéndole el cubo se lo llevó hasta la casa. Al poco tiempo vi reaparecer al joven con unas herramientas en la mano y cruzar el campo que había detrás de la casa. Asimismo, la joven también estaba ocupada, a veces dentro de la casa y otras en el patio.

tr_translation: After meeting my needs in this way, I decided to stay in this barn until something happened to change my decision. This place was truly like paradise compared to the gloomy forest, the rain-leaking branches, and the wet soil of my old home. I had enjoyed my breakfast and was about to lift a log to get some water when I heard footsteps. When I looked through a small hole, I saw a girl carrying a bucket over her head passing by my barn. She was a very young girl and, unlike the villagers and the servants at the farmhouse I had seen until then, she looked very kind. However, her clothing was coarse; she wore nothing but a blue skirt made of poor fabric and a linen jacket. Her blonde hair was braided but simple. She had a resolute but sad demeanor. Then she disappeared from sight, but about fifteen minutes later, she reappeared with a bucket now half-filled with milk. As she walked, clearly struggling to carry her load, a young man with an even more somber expression on his face appeared before her. After saying a few troubled words, the young man took the bucket from her and carried it to the hut himself. The girl followed him and they disappeared from sight. The young man soon reappeared with tools and equipment in hand and crossed the field behind the hut from end to end. The girl was sometimes busy with housework and sometimes with garden work.

Her blonde hair was braided but she wore no ornaments. Her features revealed resignation, but her appearance was sad. I lost sight of her, but after about fifteen minutes she reappeared with the same container, now half full of milk. As she walked, clearly uncomfortable with the weight, a young man with an even more depressed face approached her. With a melancholic air, they exchanged a few words, and taking the bucket from her, he carried it to the house. Soon after, I saw the young man reappear with some tools in his hand and cross the field behind the house. Likewise, the young woman was also busy, sometimes inside the house and other times in the yard.

st: "Ka lebaka leo, ke ile ka etsa qeto ea ho lula sebakeng sena ho fihlela ho hong ho ka etsahalang hore ke fetole boikemisetso ba ka. Ka sebele e ne e le paradeise e bapisoang le morung o leshoe, bolulo ba ka ba mehleng, makalana a ho theola pula le dank lefatšeng. Ke jele lijo tsa hoseng tsa hoseng ka thabo 'me ke ne ke le haufi le ho tlosa lere la ho iphumanela metsi hanyane ha ke utloa mohato, ke shebile chink e nyane, ke ile ka bona sebōpuoa se senyenyane, ka pail hloohong ea hae, ke feta ka pel'a hovel ea ka. Ngoanana enoa o ne a le monyane ebile a le motle, ho fapana le seo ke se fumaneng ho tloha ha ke fumana balebeli ba li-cottages le bahlanka ba polasing ba lokelang ho ba teng. O ne a apere ka mokhoa o ts'rileng, 'mala o moputsoa o moputsoa le jacket ea line ke ea hae feela garb; Moriri oa hae o motle o ne o le motle, empa o ne a sa khone ho shebahala a le bohloko. Ke ile ka mo bona, 'me hoo e ka bang kotara ea hora o ile a khutlela ho beha pail, eo hona joale e neng e tletse lebese. Ha a ntse a tsamaea, ho bonahala eka ke moroalo, mohlankana o ile a kopana le eena, eo sefahleho sa hae se ile sa bontša ho hloka tlhompho e tebileng. Ha a ntse a bua ka melumo e seng mekae ka moea oa melancholy, o ile a nka pail hloohong ea hae 'me a e jere ka ntlo ka boeena. 'Me o ile a latela, 'me ba ile ba nyamela. Kajeno ke ile ka bona mohlankana eo hape, ka lisebelisoa tse ling letsohong la hae, ka tšela tšimo ka morao ho cottage; Ngoanana le eena o ne a le motle, ka linako tse ling a le ka tlung mme ka linako tse ling a le ka tlung.
yo: "Ni bayi, Mo pinnu lati gbe ni hovel yii titi nkan yoo fi ṣẹlẹ eyiti o le yi ipinnu mi pada. Párádísè ni ní ìfiwéra pẹ̀lú igbó tí kò dára, ibùgbé mi tẹ́lẹ̀, àwọn ẹ̀ka òjò ń rọ̀, àti ilẹ̀ tó rọ̀. Mo jẹ oúnjẹ àárọ̀ mi pẹ̀lú ìdùnnú mo sì fẹ́ yọ pátákò kan kúrò láti ra omi díẹ̀ fún ara mi nígbà tí mo gbọ́ ìgbésẹ̀ kan, mo sì ń wo chink kékeré kan, mo rí ọ̀dọ́ ẹ̀dá kan, pẹ̀lú pail lórí rẹ̀, tí ó kọjá níwájú ìpele mi. Ọmọbìnrin náà kéré ó sì jẹ́ ìwà pẹ̀lẹ́pẹ̀lẹ́, kì í ṣe ohun tí mo ti rí àwọn ilé àti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ilé oko láti jẹ́. Síbẹ̀ ó múra dáadáa, aṣọ aláwọ̀ búlúù aláwọ̀ búlúù àti jákẹ́ẹ̀tì aṣọ aṣọ Wọ́n ṣe irun rẹ̀ tó dára ṣùgbọ́n kò ṣe ọ̀ṣọ́: ó dàbí aláìsàn síbẹ̀ ó bani nínú jẹ́. Mo pàdánù ojú rẹ̀, àti pé ní bíi ìdá mẹ́rin wákàtí kan ó padà pẹ̀lú pail náà, èyí tí ó kún fún wàrà báyìí. Bí ó ṣe ń rìn lọ, ó jọ pé ẹrù náà kò bá a mu, ọ̀dọ́mọkùnrin kan pàdé rẹ̀, tí ìrísí rẹ̀ ṣàfihàn ìbànújẹ́ tó jinlẹ̀. Nígbà tí ó ń sọ àwọn ohùn díẹ̀ pẹ̀lú afẹ́fẹ́ ìbànújẹ́, ó gbé pail náà kúrò ní orí rẹ̀ ó sì gbé e lọ sí ilé náà fúnra rẹ̀. Ó tẹ̀lé e, wọ́n sì pòórá. Lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ báyìí mo tún rí ọ̀dọ́mọkùnrin náà, pẹ̀lú àwọn irinṣẹ́ kan ní ọwọ́ rẹ̀, kọjá pápá lẹ́yìn ilé náà; Àti pé ọmọbìnrin náà tún máa ń ṣiṣẹ́, nígbà mìíràn nínú ilé àti nígbà mìíràn ní àgbàlá.
tn: "Fa ke sena go dira jalo, ke ne ka dira tshwetso ya gore go nne le sengwe se se ka dirang gore ke fetole tsela e ke akanyang ka yone. Ruri e ne e le paradaise fa e bapisiwa le sekgwa se se bofitlha, bonno jwa me jwa pele, makala a pula le lefatshe la dank. Ke ne ka ja dijo tsa mo mosong ka boitumelo mme ke ne ke le gaufi le go ntsha polane go reka metsinyana fa ke ne ke utlwa kgato, ke lebile sekaka se sennye, ka bona sebopiwa se sennye se se nang le pail mo tlhogong ya gagwe, ka feta fa pele ga fa ke le mo tseleng. Mosetsana yo o ne a le monnye e bile a le pelontle, go farologana le se ke neng ke na le sone fa ke ne ke sa ntse ke na le di-cottages le tsa kwa polaseng. Le fa go ntse jalo, o ne a apere diaparo tse di nang le mmala o o hibidu o o sweufetseng mme o ne a le mohibidu o le mongwe fela; Le fa go ntse jalo, moriri wa gagwe o ne o le mo kutlobotlhokong, mme o ne a sa ntse a le mo kutlobotlhokong. Ke ne ka mo bona, mme mo e ka nnang kotara ya ura o ne a boa a tshotse pail e e neng e tletse mašwi. Fa a ntse a tsamaya, o ne a lebega a le mokgweleo, mosimane mongwe o ne a kopana le ene, yo o neng a mo rata thata. Fa a sena go utlwa lentswe le lennye le le nang le modumo o o kwa godimo, o ne a tswa mo tlhogong ya gagwe a bo a le tsenya mo lesing la gagwe. Ba ne ba setse morago, mme ba a nyelela. 11Jwale ka bona moshanyana eo hape, a tshwere dithulusi tse ding letsohong la hae, a tlola tshimo ka morao ho ntlo; Ka dinako tse dingwe mosetsana o ne a le mo ntlong mme ka dinako tse dingwe o ne a le mo ntlong.
ty: " No te mea ua horo'ahia mai te reira, ua faaoti au i te faaea i roto i teie nei fare e tae noa'tu i te taime e tupu mai ai te tahi mea o te nehenehe e taui i ta'u faaotiraa. Ua riro mau â te reira ei paradaiso ia faaauhia i te uru raau peapea, to ' u nohoraa tahito, te mau amaa tei topa i raro i te ûa, e te fenua tei î i te ûa. Ua amu vau i ta'u tamaaraa i te po'ipo'i ma te oaoa e te faaineine ra vau i te tatara i te hoê iri no te hopu i te pape ia faaroo ana'e au i te hoê taahiraa avae, e ia hi'o ana'e au na roto i te hoê apu na'ina'i, ua ite atu vau i te hoê mea apî, e te hoê pakete i ni'a i to'na upoo, te haere ra na mua i to'u ahu. E tamahine apî teie e te mǎrû, taa ê atu i te mau mea o ta ' u i ite mai i muri iho, te mau fare faaapu e te mau tavini o te fare faaapu. Noa'tu râ i te reira, ua oomo oia i te ahu uouo, te hoê pereue ninamu e te hoê pereue vavai, o to'na ana'e ïa ahu ; ua paherehia to'na rouru uouo aita râ i paherehia : e hoho'a mata faaoroma'i to'na e e mea oto râ. Aita vau i ite faahou ia ' na, e i roto i te area e 25 hora, ua ho'i mai oia ma te amo i te pa'epa'e, tei î roa hoi i te û i teie nei. A haere noa ai oia, ma te mana'o-ore-hia i te teimaha, ua farerei maira te hoê taure'are'a ia'na, e ua anaana roa to'na hoho'a mata. Ma te faaroo i te tahi mau ta'i na roto i te hoê mata'i mo'e, ua rave a'era oia i te pa'epa'e mai nia mai i to ' na upoo e ua tuu atura i nia i te fare nainai. Ua pee oia i muri iho, e ua moe ratou. I teie taime, ua ite faahou vau i taua taure'are'a ra, e te tahi mau tauihaa i roto i to'na rima, i te haereraa na roto i te faaapu i muri i te fare ; e ua ite-atoa-hia teie tamahine, i te tahi mau taime i roto i te fare e i te tahi taime i roto i te aua.

mai: "एहि तरहें प्रदान कयल गेलासँ हम एहि खोपड़ीमे रहबाक संकल्प लेलहुँ जाबत धरि किछु एहन नहि भऽ जाय जे हमर दृढ़ संकल्पकेँ बदलि सकैत अछि। ई वास्तव मे अंधकारमय जंगल, हमर पूर्व निवास, बरखासँ खसैत डारि, आ डंक पृथ्वीक तुलनामे स्वर्ग छल। हम अपन नाश्ता खुशीसँ खयलहुँ आ अपना लेल कने पानि खरीदबाक लेल एकटा तख्ता निकालय बला छलहुँ, तखन एकटा डेग सुनलहुँ, आ एकटा छोट ठोड़ीसँ देखैत हम एकटा युवा प्राणी देखलहुँ, जकर माथ पर पेल छल, जे हमर खोपड़ीक आगू सँ गुजरि रहल छल। लड़की जवान छलीह आ सौम्य आचरणक छलीह, जकर विपरीत हमरा तखन सँ कोटेजर आ फार्महाउसक नौकर भेटल अछि। तइयो ओ नीच वस्त्र पहिरने छलीह, एकटा मोटगर नीला पेटीकोट आ लिनेन जैकेट हुनकर एकमात्र वस्त्र छल; हुनकर गोरा केश लेपित छल मुदा सजाओल नहि छल: ओ धैर्यवान मुदा उदास देखाइत छलीह। हम ओकर दृष्टि गमा लेलहुँ, आ लगभग एक चौथाई घंटाक भीतर ओ पेल लऽ कऽ घुरि अयलीह, जे आब आंशिक रूपसँ दूधसँ भरल छल। जखनि ओ बोझसँ अप्रभावित प्रतीत होइत आगू बढ़ैत चलि रहल छलीह, एकटा युवक हुनकासँ भेँट कयलक, जकर मुँह गहींर निराशा व्यक्त कयलक। उदासीनताक हवासँ किछु आवाज करैत ओ ओकर माथसँ पेल निकालि स्वयं झोपड़ीमे लऽ गेलाह। ओ पीछा केलक, आ ओ सभ गायब भए गेल। वर्तमानमे हम देखलहुँ जे युवक फेरसँ हाथमे किछु औजार लऽ कऽ कुटीरक पाछाँ खेत पार करैत अछि; आ लड़की सेहो व्यस्त छल, कखनहु घर मे आ कखनहु आँगन मे।
mg: "Rehefa nomena izany aho dia nanapa-kevitra ny hitoetra ao amin'io hovel io mandra-pahatongan'ny zavatra mety hanova ny fahavononako. Tena paradisa tokoa izany raha oharina amin'ny ala maizim-pito, ny trano fonenako taloha, ny sampana manorana ary ny tany mando. Nihinana tamim-pifaliana ny sakafo marainako aho ary saika hanala hazo fisaka iray mba hahazoana rano kely rehefa nandre dingana iray, ary nijery tamin'ny alalan'ny saoka kely iray, dia nahita zava-manan'aina tanora iray aho, niaraka tamin'ny pail teo amin'ny lohany, nandalo teo anoloan'ny kitrotro. Tanora sy tsara fanahy ilay zazavavy, tsy tahaka ny hitako hatramin'izay fa ireo mpanao trano bongo sy ireo mpiasan'ny toeram-pambolena sy fiompiana. Kanefa dia niakanjo ratsy izy, petticoat manga manopy manga sy akanjo rongony fotsy no hany akanjo tokana ho azy; Nosintonina ny volony tsara tarehy saingy tsy noravahana: toa nanam-paharetana izy nefa nalahelo. Tsy nahita azy intsony aho, ary tao anatin'ny ampahefatry ny adiny iray teo ho eo dia niverina nitondra ilay pail, izay feno ronono amin'ny ampahany ankehitriny. Rehefa nandeha teny an-dalana izy, izay toa tsy rototra tamin'ilay enta-mavesatra, dia nifanena taminy ny zatovolahy iray, izay naneho fahakiviana lalina kokoa ny endriny. Nanonona feo vitsivitsy tamin'ny rivotra mampalahelo izy ary naka ny pail avy amin'ny lohany ary nitondra izany tany amin'ny trano fialan-tsasatra. Nanaraka azy izy, ary nanjavona izy ireo. Nahita ilay tovolahy indray aho, niaraka tamin'ny fitaovana teny an-tanany, niampita ny saha tao ambadiky ny tranokely; Ary sahirana ihany koa ilay zazavavy, indraindray ao an-trano ary indraindray ao an-tokotany.

en: “They were not entirely happy. The young man and his companion often went apart and appeared to weep. I saw no cause for their unhappiness, but I was deeply affected by it. If such lovely creatures were miserable, it was less strange that I, an imperfect and solitary being, should be wretched. Yet why were these gentle beings unhappy? They possessed a delightful house (for such it was in my eyes) and every luxury; they had a fire to warm them when chill and delicious viands when hungry; they were dressed in excellent clothes; and, still more, they enjoyed one another’s company and speech, interchanging each day looks of affection and kindness. What did their tears imply? Did they really express pain? I was at first unable to solve these questions, but perpetual attention and time explained to me many appearances which were at first enigmatic.

Hoş bir eve (bana öyle görünüyordu) ve her tür konfora sahiptiler. Üşüdüklerinde onları ısıtacak bir ocakları, acıktıklarında yiyebilecek lezzetli yemekleri vardı. es: Pero no eran del todo dichosos. El joven y su compañera con frecuencia se retiraban, y parecían llorar. No comprendía la causa de su tristeza; pero me afectaba profundamente. Si seres tan hermosos eran desdichados, no era de extrañar que yo, criatura imperfecta y solitaria, también lo fuera. Pero ¿por qué eran infelices aquellas gentes tan bondadosas? Tenían una agradable casa (pues así me parecía) y todas las comodidades; tenían un fuego para calentarlos del frío y deliciosa comida con que saciar su hambre; vestían buenos trajes, y, lo que es más, disfrutaban de su mutua compañía y conversación, intercambiando a diario miradas de afecto y bondad. ¿Qué significaba su llanto? ¿Expresaban sus lágrimas dolor? No podía, al principio, responderme a estas preguntas, pero el tiempo y una sostenida observación me explicaron muchas cosas que a primera vista parecían enigmáticas.

en: “As the night advanced, a fierce wind arose from the woods and quickly dispersed the clouds that had loitered in the heavens; the blast tore along like a mighty avalanche and produced a kind of insanity in my spirits that burst all bounds of reason and reflection. I lighted the dry branch of a tree and danced with fury around the devoted cottage, my eyes still fixed on the western horizon, the edge of which the moon nearly touched. A part of its orb was at length hid, and I waved my brand; it sank, and with a loud scream I fired the straw, and heath, and bushes, which I had collected. The wind fanned the fire, and the cottage was quickly enveloped by the flames, which clung to it and licked it with their forked and destroying tongues.

en: “I generally rested during the day and travelled only when I was secured by night from the view of man. One morning, however, finding that my path lay through a deep wood, I ventured to continue my journey after the sun had risen; the day, which was one of the first of spring, cheered even me by the loveliness of its sunshine and the balminess of the air. I felt emotions of gentleness and pleasure, that had long appeared dead, revive within me. Half surprised by the novelty of these sensations, I allowed myself to be borne away by them, and forgetting my solitude and deformity, dared to be happy. Soft tears again bedewed my cheeks, and I even raised my humid eyes with thankfulness towards the blessed sun, which bestowed such joy upon me.

vi_translation: Usually, during the day, I find a place to rest, only hitting the road when the night safely shields me from human eyes. However, that morning, seeing the road running through a dense forest, I took the risk of continuing even though the sun had already risen. It was an early spring day, the sunlight was so lovely, and the air was fragrant, making even me feel cheerful. I felt gentle and pleasant emotions that I had long thought dead come back to life. Almost surprised by these feelings, I let them carry me away; forgetting my loneliness and deformity, I even dared to feel happy. Tears softly streamed down my cheeks, and I even looked up with wet eyes to thank the benevolent sun for granting me such joy.

en: “While I was overcome by these feelings, I left the spot where I had committed the murder, and seeking a more secluded hiding-place, I entered a barn which had appeared to me to be empty. A woman was sleeping on some straw; she was young, not indeed so beautiful as her whose portrait I held, but of an agreeable aspect and blooming in the loveliness of youth and health. Here, I thought, is one of those whose joy-imparting smiles are bestowed on all but me. And then I bent over her and whispered, ‘Awake, fairest, thy lover is near—he who would give his life but to obtain one look of affection from thine eyes; my beloved, awake!’

en: On the whole island there were but three miserable huts, and one of these was vacant when I arrived. This I hired. It contained but two rooms, and these exhibited all the squalidness of the most miserable penury. The thatch had fallen in, the walls were unplastered, and the door was off its hinges. I ordered it to be repaired, bought some furniture, and took possession, an incident which would doubtless have occasioned some surprise had not all the senses of the cottagers been benumbed by want and squalid poverty. As it was, I lived ungazed at and unmolested, hardly thanked for the pittance of food and clothes which I gave, so much does suffering blunt even the coarsest sensations of men.

es: En toda la isla no había más que tres míseras chozas, una de las cuales encontré desocupada al llegar. La alquilé. Tenía sólo dos cuartos, que mostraban la suciedad propia de las más absoluta indigencia. La techumbre, de ramas y rastrojos, se estaba hundiendo; las paredes no estaban encaladas, y la puerta colgaba, torcida, de uno de los goznes. Ordené que la repararan, compré algunos muebles y me instalé, lo que sin duda hubiera ocasionado bastante sorpresa de no ser porque la necesidad y la pobreza habían entumecido por completo las mentes de estos habitantes. El hecho es que ni me molestaban ni curioseaban, y apenas si me agradecieron los víveres y ropas que les di, lo que demuestra hasta qué punto el sufrimiento insensibiliza incluso los sentimientos más elementales del hombre.

vi_translation: On the entire island, there were only three shabby huts, one of which was vacant when I arrived. I rented this one. It had only two rooms, bearing the full appearance of extreme poverty. The plaster on the walls had crumbled, the straw covering the roof was tattered and falling apart, and the doors were hanging off their hinges. I had the house repaired, bought some furniture, and moved in permanently; an event that surely would have surprised the islanders, had they not been so starved and desperate that they were numb to everything. Thus, I lived without anyone watching or disturbing me, rarely receiving thanks for the little food and clothing I gave them - suffering had dulled even the most basic human emotions in them.

If the islanders' senses had not been dulled by poverty and misery, all of this would undoubtedly have caused astonishment. en: Even if they were to leave Europe and inhabit the deserts of the new world, yet one of the first results of those sympathies for which the dæmon thirsted would be children, and a race of devils would be propagated upon the earth who might make the very existence of the species of man a condition precarious and full of terror. Had I right, for my own benefit, to inflict this curse upon everlasting generations? I had before been moved by the sophisms of the being I had created; I had been struck senseless by his fiendish threats; but now, for the first time, the wickedness of my promise burst upon me; I shuddered to think that future ages might curse me as their pest, whose selfishness had not hesitated to buy its own peace at the price, perhaps, of the existence of the whole human race.

en: The monster saw my determination in my face and gnashed his teeth in the impotence of anger. “Shall each man,” cried he, “find a wife for his bosom, and each beast have his mate, and I be alone? I had feelings of affection, and they were requited by detestation and scorn. Man! You may hate, but beware! Your hours will pass in dread and misery, and soon the bolt will fall which must ravish from you your happiness for ever. Are you to be happy while I grovel in the intensity of my wretchedness? You can blast my other passions, but revenge remains—revenge, henceforth dearer than light or food! I may die, but first you, my tyrant and tormentor, shall curse the sun that gazes on your misery. Beware, for I am fearless and therefore powerful. I will watch with the wiliness of a snake, that I may sting with its venom. Man, you shall repent of the injuries you inflict.”

en: Ever since my recovery from the fever, I had been in the custom of taking every night a small quantity of laudanum, for it was by means of this drug only that I was enabled to gain the rest necessary for the preservation of life. Oppressed by the recollection of my various misfortunes, I now swallowed double my usual quantity and soon slept profoundly. But sleep did not afford me respite from thought and misery; my dreams presented a thousand objects that scared me. Towards morning I was possessed by a kind of nightmare; I felt the fiend’s grasp in my neck and could not free myself from it; groans and cries rang in my ears. My father, who was watching over me, perceiving my restlessness, awoke me; the dashing waves were around, the cloudy sky above, the fiend was not here: a sense of security, a feeling that a truce was established between the present hour and the irresistible, disastrous future imparted to me a kind of calm forgetfulness, of which the human mind is by its structure peculiarly susceptible.

tr_translation: Since I left my feverish period behind, I had made it a habit to take a small amount of opium tincture every night, because only with this medicine could I relax and achieve the sleep necessary to sustain my life. Under the pressure created by the memory of my misfortunes, I doubled the usual dose and fell into a deep sleep. However, sleep did not take me away from thought and sorrow. My dreams were filled with thousands of things that instilled fear in me. Towards morning, I was shaken by a terrible nightmare. I felt the hands of the devil on my throat, and I couldn't free myself. Moans and screams were ringing in my ears. When my father, who never took his eyes off me, noticed my restlessness, he woke me up. There were wild waves around, clouds in the sky, but the devil was nowhere to be seen. It was a kind of sense of security; a truce between the present and the inevitable, a peaceful forgetfulness granted by my disaster-filled future and inclined by the nature of the human mind.

vi_translation: These are the last happy moments of my life. We glided quite swiftly along the water; the sun was fierce, but we avoided the heat under a canopy while enjoying the beautiful scenery, sometimes on this side of the lake, where we saw the Saleve mountain, the cheerful shores of Montalègre, and in the distance, towering above all, the magnificent Mont Blanc, and the snow-covered mountains clustered around it, vainly competing with it; sometimes we moved to the other side of the lake to admire the majestic Jura mountains, presenting their dark face as a barrier to the greedy who wish to cross into their land, and an almost insurmountable obstacle to invaders who want to enslave it.

tr_translation: These were the last moments in my life when I could taste happiness. We were moving rapidly. The weather was hot, but we were sheltered from the sun under a canopy, enjoying the scenery. Sometimes we watched one side of the lake where we could see Mont Salêve, the beautiful shores of Montalêgre, and in the distance, the magnificent Mont Blanc rising above the entire landscape with the snow-capped mountains that envied it in vain; other times, as we progressed along the opposite shore, we saw the splendid Jura, which presented an insurmountable barrier to those who intended to abandon their country or to those who thought of dragging it into captivity.
